newsitem.title: UK: China can be trusted with Hong Kong, SE head says. [CORRECTED 29/10]
newsitem.headline: China can be trusted with Hong Kong, SE head says. [CORRECTED 29/10]

text.p: (Corrects to remove erroneous quote and references to pro-democracy groups)
The chairman of Hong Kong's stock exchange said on Thursday that China could be trusted to nurture financial markets after the territory was handed over to Beijing next year.
"China has extensive commercial interests in Hong Kong...it can be trusted to behave pragmatically," Edgar Cheng Wai-Kin told a business conference in Edinburgh.
The stock exchange chairman said Hong Kong's financial markets were in good shape and would become even more important in the future.
Hong Kong has the sixth largest Foreign Exchange market in the world and its stock market is the eighth largest -- the biggest in Asia after Japan.
The task was to maintain the integrity of existing regulatory institutions, now run by Hong Kong people who would be staying on after the handover, said Cheng.
There were fears there would be an upsurge in fraud and other malpractices as the handover neared but these were not borne out, he said.
Standards had continued to rise and accountability to shareholders had developed to a previously unheard of extent.
"China has no interest in any decline in commercial morality," said Cheng, who serves on the Chinese commission that will organise the handover.
Britain's senior trade commissioner in Hong Kong, Francis Cornish, agreed that Hong Kong will remain the main trade centre in the Asian-Pacific region after 1997.

"The greatest danger has been that of unintentional harm after China takes control, but that danger is diminishing as Chinese officials gain more experience in external affairs," Cornish told the conference.
